qas.question: Which European cities likely had populations greater than 100,000 in 1500?

answers.text: Venice, Milan, Naples, Paris and Constantinople

qas.question: How many other cities had populations larger than 40,000 by 1500?
What event decimated urban populations in the 14th century?
Which English city had a population greater than 40,000 in 1500?

plausible_answers.text: Venice, Milan, Naples, Paris and Constantinople

qas.question: Which European cities likely had populations greater than 1,000,000 in 1500?

plausible_answers.text: Venice, Milan, Naples, Paris and Constantinople

qas.question: Which European cities likely had populations less than 100,000 in 1500?
How many other cities had populations larger than 40,000 by 1600?
What event decimated urban populations in the 13th century?
Which English city had a population greater than 40,000 in 1600?

context: Up until the mid-14th century, Europe had experienced steadily increasing urbanisation. Cities were also decimated by <a2_0><b7_0>the Black Death<b7_0/><a2_0/>, but the role of urban areas as centres of learning, commerce and government ensured continued growth. By 1500, <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>Venice, Milan, Naples, Paris and Constantinople<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> each probably had more than 100,000 inhabitants. <a1_0><b6_0>Twenty-two<b6_0/><a1_0/> other cities were larger than 40,000; most of these were in Italy and the Iberian peninsula, but there were also some in France, the Empire, the Low Countries, plus <a3_0><b8_0>London<b8_0/><a3_0/> in England.
